Scheme 1 Schematic describes the photocatalytic mechanism in (a) the visible light and (b) the UV–vis light for PdOx/WO3/TiO2 system. Scheme 1 Fig. 1 X-ray diffraction patterns of (a) pure TiO2 nanofiber (sample A), WO3/TiO2 nanofibers obtained from different amount of DIAD adding: (b) 0g (sample B) and (c) 0.6g (sample E). Fig. 1 Fig. 2 (a) Nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms and (b) the corresponding pore size distribution curves of sample A-F. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 Typical SEM images (a, b) with different magnifications and the corresponding element mapping images (c-f) of DIAD/PVP/WCl6/TBOT precursor nanofiber of sample E. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 Typical SEM images with different magnifications (the inset is the average diameter distribution) of (a-c) sample E and (d-e) sample B. (f-i) EDS pattern and the corresponding elemental mapping images of sample E. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 (a) TEM and (b) HRTEM images (red frame area) of sample E and HRTEM images of (c) Area 1 and (d) Area 2 in Fig. 5b. (For interpretation of the references to colour in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article.) Fig. 5 Fig. 6 XPS spectra of sample A and sample E: (a) survey, (b) Ti 2p core-level and (c) O 1s core-level and (d) W 4f core-level. Fig. 6 Fig. 7 (a) TG/DTA spectra of polymeric precursor nanofibers of sample B (black line) and sample E (red line). (b) A typical SEM image of the precursor nanofiber of sample E calcined at 200°C for 30min (For interpretation of the references to colour in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article.) Fig. 7 Fig. 8 (a) A typical TEM image of sample E with 0.5wt% PdOx nanoparticles loading and (b) XPS spectra of Pd species. Fig. 8 Fig. 9 Absorbance spectra of (a) sample A, (b) sample E and (c) sample E with 0.5wt% PdOx loading. In the inset is given Tauc plots for indirect bandgap for sample A and sample E. Fig. 9 Fig. 10 The decomposition of acetaldehyde solution and CO2 evolution during the photocatalytic decomposition of acetaldehyde over the as-prepared samples under (a, b) visible light irradiation and (c, d) UV–vis light irradiation. Fig. 10 Fig. 11 (a) Quencher tests in the photocatalytic reaction of sample E with 0.5wt% PdOx loading under UV–vis light irradiation for 2h. (b) Results of reusability experiments for CO2 generation from the photocatalytic decomposition of acetaldehyde over sample E with 0.5wt% PdOx loading and P25 under UV–vis light irradiation. Graphical abstract Highly mesoporous WO3/TiO2 nanofibers were fabricated through the combination of an advanced electrospinning strategy in the presence of porogenic agent and the subsequent heat treatment. It was found that the introduced porogenic agent of diisopropyl azodiformate (DIAD) within the precursor solution plays a crucial role on the formation of highly mesoporous WO3/TiO2 nanofibers, enabling their mesopores tunable. The obtained mesoporous nanofibers from the stepwise decomposition of DIAD and polymer skeleton possess more homogeneous and smaller pore sizes in their morphology and thus a higher surface area than that obtained without porogenic agent. The highest surface area can reach 92.3m2g−1, which is ca. 5 times larger than that of the pure TiO2 nanofibers obtained without DIAD addition. These highly mesoporous WO3/TiO2 nanofibers were further modified by PdOx nanoparticles via photodeposition. The as-fabricated mesoporous PdOx/WO3/TiO2 hybrid nanofibers exhibit excellent photocatalytic activity and significant stability towards acetaldehyde decomposition compared to the conventional nanofibers under visible light and UV–vis light irradiation. The present work suggests a facile preparation of PdOx loaded mesoporous WO3/TiO2 nanofibers, which may provide new solution to prepare the inorganic nanofibers with highly mesoporous structure. Keywords WO3/TiO2 nanofibers Mesoporous Porogenic agent PdOx loading Photocatalysis 1 Introduction Mesoporous materials have been extensively studied for the past few decades with regard to their structure, synthesis, properties and formation mechanism because of their fascinating features such as high specific surface areas, tunable mesostructures and excellent chemical stability compared to their conventional solid counterpart [1–5]. A large number of reaction/interaction sites are related to the high surface area induced by mesoporous structure, which benefit for the interface related processes such as adsorption, catalysis and electrochemistry applications [6]. It is known that the durability problem of the particle system is still unsolved in suspending system of photocatalytic reaction, which causes the inevitable particle aggregation and active surface area loss. Recently, construction of one dimensional (1D) mesoporous nanofibers has particularly attracted extensive attention because of their broad applications in photocatalysis, optoelectronics, and biomaterials [7]. Besides their intrinsic porous features, the 1D mesoporous nanofibers possess a robust geometry to maintain the functionalities and can effectively inhibit the above mentioned aggregation [8–11]. Up to date, several synthesis methods have been developed to prepare mesoporous nanofibers, such as electrospinning technique [12,13], hydrothermal reaction [14,15] or template assisted process [16,17], and so on. However, it is still challenging to fabricate highly mesoporous nanofibers with desired uniformity in a simple method. Among the extensively studied mesoporous nanofibers, the mesoporous TiO2 nanofibers are of particular interest due to their promising applications in a wide range of fields. Unfortunately, the photo efficiency of TiO2 is substantially limited by its relatively large band gap energy (3.0–3.2eV) [18] which allows it to absorb ultraviolet (UV) light only. To date, many attempts have been explored to prolong the lifetime of photogenerated carriers for the high quantum efficiency or narrow the band gap of TiO2 for the much larger photocatalytic activity. One possible way is to introduce a low bandgap semiconductor on the TiO2 surface to form heterostructures [19,20] and WO3 is a good candidate because it has a relatively low bandgap energy (2.6eV) and capacity to absorb a broader range solar spectrum [21,22]. Additionally, coupling WO3 on TiO2 increases the acidity and affinity of WO3/TiO2 surface enabling the adsorption of greater amount of hydroxyl groups and organic pollutants on the surface [23–25]. These properties make the WO3/TiO2 system a potential catalytic material for effective photocatalysis. In recent years, various synthetic methods have been developed for preparing WO3/TiO2 composites including sol-gel [26], template-assisted rout [27], ball milling [28], hydrothermal [29], and impregnation [30]. Indeed, the WO3/TiO2 composite prepared by these methods have shown the good photocatalytic activity towards organic targets thanks to their heterostructure, which enhances the separation of photogenerated electrons and holes. In order to make the photogenerated electrons and holes separate more effectively, the noble metal (Pd) in contact with TiO2 or WO3 can be a good solution, because the Pd loading significantly enhances the overall photocatalytic activity [31]. It can be expected that the high work function of Pd favors the electron transfer and reduction of the electron-hole recombination, and its low price allows for its large-scale production and applications. In the present work, we explored a novel photocatalyst consisting of PdOx-loaded highly mesoporous WO3/TiO2 hybrid nanofibers through a porogenic agent-involved electrospinning method and subsequent noble metal photodeposition. The introduction of WO3 aims to extend light response range and reduce carriers’ recombination of WO3/TiO2 photocatalysts. The 1D construction of nanofiber favors to limit photocatalyst aggregation, keeping the stability of the photocatalytic activity. Importantly, the porogenic agent in this study is used as the first stage porogen during the calcination of the as-spun precursor nanofibers and leads to the formation of the more highly mesoporous WO3/TiO2 nanofibers than that obtained without porogenic agent addition. The addition of porogenic agent largely enhanced the specific surface area of the WO3/TiO2 nanofibers with smaller pore diameter. The mesoporous fibers were subsequently photodeposited by Pd nanoparticles which can more effectively enhance the separation efficiency of the photogenerated electrons and holes. The resultant PdOx-loaded highly mesoporous WO3/TiO2 nanofibers exhibit much better photocatalytic performance than the conventional nanofibers and the commercial available P25 and good stability, suggesting their promising application prospect. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Materials The raw materials of polyvinylpyrrolidone (PVP, degree of polymerization: MW≈1300000), WCl6 (99%), tetrabutyl titanate (TBOT), palladium chloride (PdCl2). Diisopropyl azodiformate (DIAD), acetaldehyde (AcH), isopropyl alcohol (IPA), p-benzoquinone (BQ) and triethanolamine (TEOA) were commercially available from Wako Pure Chemicals Ind., Ltd., Japan and used directly without further purification. The solvents used in this study are absolute ethanol and N, N- N- dimethylformamide (DMF, Wako Pure Chemicals Ind., Ltd., Japan), respectively. 2.2 Experimental procedures 2.2.1 Preparation of highly mesoporous WO3/TiO2 hybrid nanofibers with DIAD addition The highly mesoporous WO3/TiO2 nanofibers were synthesized by electrospinning approach followed by the subsequent calcination process. In a typical process, 0.35g of PVP was dissolved in the mixed solvent (3.65g of absolute ethanol and 1g of DMF) by vigorously stirring for 3h. Then, 1g of TBOT and 0.04g of WCl6 (The reason for choosing 0.04g of WCl6 was explained in details (Fig. S1 and S2 , table S1 and S2) in the supporting information.) were added into the above polymer solution, followed by vigorous stirring at room temperature for 30min. After that, the porogenic agent DIAD was added in the above precursor solution with well mixture. The adding amounts of DIAD were 0, 0.2, 0.4, 0.6 and 1.0g, respectively. The obtained solutions were then transferred into a plastic syringe with a typical fixed distance of 15cm between the top of the nozzle and the collector. Voltage of 20kV was applied between these two electrodes via a high-voltage power supply. Electrospinning was conducted under environmental conditions. The as-spun polymer samples were referred as DIAD/PVP/WCl6/TBOT precursor fibers, which then were heated to 500°C at a heating rate of 4°Cmin−1, maintained at 500°C for 2h in air, and cooled in a furnace to ambient temperature. As a comparison, the pure TiO2 nanofibers were also prepared using the above preparation process without adding WCl6 and DIAD. The details for these six initial solutions were presented in Table 1 , and the resultant calcined samples were referred to sample A–F, respectively. 2.2.2 PdOx loading by photodeposition Pd nanoparticles were loaded onto the WO3/TiO2 nanofibers via the following photodeposition method. The necessary amounts of PdCl2 powder (0.1, 0.5 and 1wt%, calculated relative to the amount of photocatalyst particles) was dissolved to give a 9.3mmolL−1 HCl aqueous solution, forming the PdCl4 2− complex, which was then added to the suspension of photocatalyst particles as a precursor for photodeposition [32]. UV lamp (365nm, 32W) was used as the light source, with photoirradiation carried out for 3h. After three repeated washings with distilled water and centrifugation, the sample was dried in air at 60°C for 10h. 2.3 Characterization The as-prepared samples were characterized with field emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM, Zeiss Ultra55, Germany), X-ray powder diffraction (XRD, Rigaku Miniflex II, Japan) using a CuKα with a Ni filter(30kV, 15mA) and a transmission electron microscope (TEM, JEOL JEM-2100, Japan). The porous properties of the as-prepared mesoporous nanofibers were characterized using N2 adsorption at −196°C on a specific surface area and porosity analyzer (Micromeritics, TRYSTAR 3000, USA). The thermal behaviors of the as-spun precursors were analyzed by a TG-DTA thermoanalyzer (Shimadzu DTG-60, Japan) from 30°C to 600°C with a heating rate of 10°C/min in air. The surface composition was investigated using X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, JPS-9010MC, JEOL Ltd. Japan). The optical information of the as-prepared samples was measured by UV–vis diffuse reflectance spectroscopy (Shimadzu, UV-2400PC/2500PC, Japan). 2.4 Photocatalytic performance evaluation For the photocatalytic reactor, a high pressure Hg lamp (500W, 300<λ<600nm, light intensity 600μWCm−2) was located in the center of the reactor along the axis and protected by a water-cooled quartz jacket. Thus the visible light (equipped with cutoff filter (L42, Hoya) between the Hg lamp and Pyrex test tube) was collected into the sealed Pyrex test tube (55mL) and ensured the photocatalytic reaction performed uniformly and completely. The reactor was fitted with a magnetic stirrer for stirring at 400rpm to keep the catalyst in suspension. The overall photocatalytic activity was tested as the amounts of CO2 gas that originated from the oxidation decomposition of aqueous acetaldehyde solution (1 vol%, ca. 350μmol, pH=6.2) containing a suspension of the photocatalyst powder (40mg) under the irradiation of the visible light (420<λ<600nm) and UV–vis light (300<λ<600nm) at 25°C. The reaction stoichiometry of acetaldehyde has been ascertained to be following: CH3CHO+5/2O2 →2CO2 +2H2O Gas Chromatography (GC7890II, Techcomp) equipped with Flame Ionization Detector (FID) for the concentration of acetaldehyde in solution. The CO2 concentrations were measured using a gas chromatography (Align model GC-6890N) equipped with a 2m Porapak-Q column, a methanizer, and a flame ionization detector, using N2 as the carrier gas. 2.5 The measurement of produced H2O2 amount The amount of H2O2 produced during the photocatalytic decomposition of acetaldehyde was analyzed with iodometry, as followings. After the photocatalysts were filtered, potassium iodide (KI) aqueous solution (0.4molL−1, 1mL) and potassium hydrogen phthalate (C8H5KO4) aqueous solution (0.1molL−1, 1mL) were dropped to the solution. The mixed solution was then kept for 5min. The generated H2O2 molecules could react with iodide anions (I−) under acidic conditions (H2O2 +3I− +2H+ →I3− +2H2O). And then triiodide anions (I3−) were produced, which have a strong absorption at around 350nm. The amount of I3− was determined by means of UV–vis spectroscopy (Shimadzu, UV-2400PC/2500PC) according to the absorbance at 350nm, from which the amount of H2O2 produced during each reaction was estimated. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 The effect of DIAD addition Fig. 1 illustrates the XRD patterns of pure TiO2 nanofibers and WO3/TiO2 obtained without and with DIAD addition. In all samples, only the TiO2 anatase phase characteristic peaks (JCPDS, Card No. 21-1272) could be observed. No diffraction peaks of WO3 were observed, which was likely due to the low amount of WO3 loading out of the available detection range (Fig. 1b and 1c). The intensities of the anatase phase decrease by adding the amount of tungsten. The peaks that belong to (105) and (211) become not sharp and unclear which may also be due to the introduction of tungsten. It is noted that the precursor of WO3/TiO2 composites shows only the peak that belongs to the PVP polymer in XRD pattern (Fig. S3); no peak detection of the precursor of WO3 may be due to the low content. In addition, the porogenic agent has no effect on the change of crystalline and compositions of the resultants samples. The effect of the DIAD adding amounts on the specific surface area and pore distribution of the resultant samples was further investigated. Fig. 2 shows the nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms and the corresponding pore size distribution curves for the pure TiO2 nanofibers (sample A) and WO3/TiO2 nanofibers (samples B-F) obtained with increasing DIAD amounts. All the nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms exhibit type IV curves with H3 hysteresis, indicating the presence of mesoporous structures (Fig. 2a) [33]. The information about the specific surface area and pore size distribution was presented in Table 2 . As shown in Table 2, the specific surface areas of Samples C-F increases with increasing DIAD content, from 73.2 to 92.3m2g−1, which are larger than that of sample B obtained without DIAD addition (55.4m2g−1), suggesting that even a small adding amount of DIAD could greatly increase the specific surface area of the as-prepared sample. The highest surface area (92.3m2g−1 for sample E) is ca. 5 times larger than that of the pure TiO2 nanofibers obtained without DIAD addition. The results are further confirmed by the corresponding pore size distribution (Fig. 2b). The peak pore diameters of the samples B-F gradually decrease with increasing DIAD content, and sample E has the minimum pore diameter with an average pore size of 3.84nm. However, for sample F, the excess quantity of DIAD addition may in turn destroy the fiber structure, resulting in the decrease of the specific surface area. Evidently, our synthetic strategy is unique to simply achieve a fine-tuning of the mesopore diameter in a relatively large range by adjusting the amount of the porogenic agent. On the basis of the above results, sample E with the highest BET was chosen to characterize the evolution of the mesoporous WO3/TiO2 nanofibers in the next sections. 3.2 The evolution of highly mesoporous structure obtained with DIAD addition Fig. 3 a and 3b display the SEM images of the precursor nanofibers of sample E with different magnifications. The as-spun precursor fibers possessed a well-defined 1D fiber structure with smooth and solid surface and the average diameter of ca. 261nm, which had almost no difference from the precursor fibers of sample B obtained without DIAD addition (Fig. S4), suggesting that the DIAD addition did not affect the formation of fiber structure during the electrospinning process. The corresponding elemental mappings disclose uniform spatial distribution of Ti, W, O and N as shown in Fig. 3c–f. The uniform distribution of N throughout the fiber body indicated that DIAD molecules were uniformly distributed throughout the whole body of precursor nanofibers. The SEM images of the calcined precursor nanofibers (sample E) at 500°C were presented in Fig. 4 a–c. An integrated 1D nanofiber structure was also observed in the calcined WO3/TiO2 samples with reduced average diameter of ca. 198nm (inset in Fig. 4a), which also showed no any significantly change with sample B obtained without DIAD addition (Fig. 4d) in low magnification. However, compared to the irregular and distorted surface of sample B (Fig. 4e), the surface of sample E obtained with DIAD addition has a thoroughly porous structure with relatively compact and homogeneous pores from the observation of the cross section SEM images (Fig. 4b and 4c). Meanwhile, the particles that composed of the pores also became much smaller and more regular with spherical shape and relatively uniform size. According to our previous study, we have utilized the DIAD to prepare the highly mesoporous TiO2 nanotubes with intact tubular morphology, where the DIAD as the first-staged porogenic agent made the tube wall porous and provided the ventilation passage way for the large amount of released vapors from the subsequent decomposition of template (PVA), protecting the tube wall from the damage [34]. Herein, we ascribed that the above differences in morphology change were due to the decomposition of DIAD which also worked as the first-staged porogen within the entire fiber body and reduced the possibility of damage to the fibers in the subsequent decomposition of PVP, leading to the uniform and homogeneous mesoporous structure. The composition of sample E was further investigated by EDS and the corresponding elemental mapping measurement (Fig. 4f–i). The results show that only Ti, W and O were observed without element N detected, suggesting the DIAD porogenic agent in the nanofibers was completely decomposed by thermal treatment and also implying that the well-mixed heterojunctions could have been composed of TiO2 and WO3. Moreover, the atomic W/Ti ratio was calculated to be 0.039, which has good agreement with the adding W/Ti ratio (0.034). TEM was furtherly used for determining the porous structure of sample E, as shown in Fig. 5 a. It clearly confirmed that well distributed pores were formed throughout the entire fiber. The SAED pattern (the inset in Fig. 5a) recorded at the edge of the fiber suggests that the calcined samples were anatase TiO2, too, which is quite consistent with the result of the XRD pattern (Fig. 1c). Fig. 5b–d present the high magnification TEM images of the samples. Two different sets of lattice fringes were observed and the measured d-space of 0.356nm (Fig. 5c) and 0.384nm (Fig. 5d) between these two different sets of fringes corresponds to the (100) plane of the anatase TiO2 and the (002) plane of the hexagonal WO3, respectively. X-ray Photoelectron emission (XPS) measurements were employed to elucidate the chemical states for the calcined samples. As shown in Fig. 6 a, the fully scanned spectrum clearly shows that elements of Ti, O, W, and C signals exist in sample E, which is consistent with the result of EDS. The presence of carbon element in the final sample may be related to the use of carbon tape. Fig. 6b–d further show the high-resolution spectra of the Ti 2p, O 1s and W 4f regions, respectively. The Ti 2p core level spectrum could be well fitted into two groups of spin–orbit doublets after deconvolution. The peaks locate at 463.5 and 457.9eV could be attributed to the spin–orbit splitting of the TiO2 components (Ti 2p1/2 and Ti 2p3/2) in WO3/TiO2 nanofibers (sample E). The binding energies of Ti 2p1/2 and Ti 2p3/2 of the pure TiO2 nanofibers (sample A) are located at 463.3 and 457.7eV, respectively. This slight positive shift is attributed to the presence of tungsten in the lattice of TiO2 as WOTi linkage. It thus infers that W ions are incorporated into the TiO2 lattice and displace some Ti4+ ions due to the near ionic radius of W6+ and Ti4+(0.065nm vs. 0.062nm) [35]. After deconvolution of the O 1s, pure TiO2 and mesoporous WO3/TiO2 nanofibers show two fitted peaks. The major peaks located at 528.9–529.2eV contributing to Ti–O and W–O, respectively, while the broad peaks at 531.2eV correspond to OH groups for sample E [36,37], which was broader than that in sample A (Fig. 6c). This clearly indicates that the WO3/TiO2 has more hydroxyl groups as well as surface adsorbed water than the pure TiO2. It has been well reported that pure WO3 shows typical W 4f7/2 and 4f5/2 peaks at 35.3 and 37.4eV, respectively [38–40]. In our case, the positions of W 4f7/2 and W 4f5/2 are slightly higher at 38.1 and 36eV in sample E (Fig. 6d). It has good agreement with the results of hexavalent oxidation state of WO3 in the above literatures. The peak shift of binding energy may be due to the formation of WOTi bond as mentioned above. Thus, the oxidation state of the incorporated tungsten species is W6+. Moreover, the nitrogen was not detected in XPS spectrum (Fig. S5), suggesting that the DIAD (nitrogen source) was totally decomposed during the heat-treatment, which is good agreement with the results of the EDS measurement. 3.3 Plausible mechanism of the highly mesoporous formation The thermal decomposition processes of the as-spun precursor nanofibers of sample B and sample E were investigated by TG-DTA analysis (Fig. 7 a). The weight loss at the first stage from 30 to 170°C) can be ascribed to the decomposition of the adsorbed water and the residual solvent. The 8% weight loss from 170 to 240°C is attributed to the decomposition of DIAD molecules. The sequent 35% weight loss from 240 to 480°C) is due to the decomposition of PVP. Finally, the DTA exothermic peak at 500°C is attributed to the TiO2 and WO3 crystallization. In contrast, only the exothermic peak related to PVP decomposition was observed for the precursor fibers of sample B. According to the mentioned results of thermal performance of the precursor nanofiber, the effect of DIAD on the formation of the relatively uniform and highly mesoporous nanofibers could be explained as followings: the porogenic agent DIAD was first uniformly dissolved into the PVP/WCl6/TBOT precursor solutions. The DIAD molecules were distributed homogeneously within the precursor fibers after being electrospun which were evidenced by elemental mapping observation. During the first stage of calcination process under air at 500°C, the DIAD was completely decomposed into large amounts of gases (e.g., CO2, NO2, and H2O), which resulted in the formation of the initial pores throughout the entire fiber body. This stage can be evidenced by the SEM image of the DIAD/PVP/WCl6/TBOT precursor nanofibers of sample E calcined at 200°C for 30min, where the surface became to appear porous structure throughout the fiber (Fig. 7b). Secondly, these initial mesopores caused by the DIAD decomposition provided the ventilation channels for released massive vapors from the subsequent decomposition of PVP skeleton, which protected the entire fiber from the impact of the released massive gases without damage. Therefore, it is precisely due to such kind of “stepwise decompositions” of the porogenic agent and polymer resulting in this unique highly mesoporous structure of the as-prepared samples. 3.4 PdOx loading of the highly mesoporous WO3/TiO2 nanofiber (sample E) The highly mesoporous WO3/TiO2 nanofibers (sample E) were subsequently modified by Pd nanoparticles loading. Fig. 8 a shows the TEM image of sample E loaded with 0.5wt% Pd cocatalyst. The loaded Pd nanoparticles with diameters of ca.8–20nm were observed to be well distributed on the surface of the fiber. The chemical state of Pd species was further confirmed by XPS measurement, along with those of PdO and Pd for comparison. The Pd-loaded species on the surface of WO3/TiO2 nanofiber were found to contain both PdII and Pd0 species as shown in Fig. 8b. The Pd species on WO3/TiO2 nanofiber were presumed to be Pd oxide, i.e., PdO, judging from good agreement with the peak position in reference PdO. Considering the reduction potential from PdCl4 2− to Pd metal (+0.6V vs standard hydrogen electrode (SHE)), the lower level of CBM in WO3 (+0.5V vs SHE) than in TiO2 (−0.2V vs SHE), i.e. the lower reduction potential of photoexcited electrons, might be the reason for incomplete reduction of Pd on WO3 [32]. It thus infers that Pd nanoparticles not only deposited on the surface of TiO2 but also a part on the surface of WO3. Therefore, the WO3/TiO2 samples loaded with Pd species will, hereafter, be denoted as PdOx/WO3/TiO2 because they contain both Pd0 and PdII (i.e., PdO) To better understand the photocatalytic efficiency in the as-synthesized samples, diffuse reflectance spectra (Fig. 9 ) were used to determine the bandgap energy. The bandgaps (Eg) were calculated to be 3.17eV and 2.83eV for sample A and sample E, as shown in the inset of Fig. 9. The sample E with 0.5wt% PdOx loading shows an increased absorbance above 400nm compared to sample E and sample A due to the light scattering by the Pd particles [41]. 3.5 Photocatalytic performance Photocatalytic activities of the as-prepared samples were investigated using acetaldehyde solution decomposition as a model reaction under visible light (Fig. 10 a and b) and UV–vis light irradiation (Fig. 10c and d). Before light irradiation, the mesoporous WO3/TiO2 composites (sample B and sample E) showing higher adsorption to acetaldehyde than P25 and the pure TiO2 nanofibers (sample A) may be due to their mesoporous structure with higher specific surface area. The obtained results have demonstrated that the highly mesoporous PdOx/WO3/TiO2 nanofibers (sample E) are active and efficient photocatalysts for the photodecomposition of acetaldehyde as compared to Degussa P25, the pure TiO2 nanofibers (sample A) and WO3/TiO2 nanofibers obtained without DIAD addition (sample B) and with DIAD addition (sample E) under visible light as shown in Fig. 10a. Acetaldehyde was ca. 97.8% decomposed by the sample E with 0.5wt% PdOx loading within 7h, compared to the degradation of 75.4% for sample E and 60.8% for sample B. As contrast, pure TiO2 nanofibers (sample A) and Degussa P25 showed little degradation of acetaldehyde in visible light due to their larger band gap value. As to the case in UV–vis Irradiation, the trend of the photocatalytic activities of the as-prepared photocatalysts was similar to that in visible light irradiation (Fig. 10c). All of the photocatalysts showed higher activity towards acetaldehyde. Acetaldehyde was almost completely decomposed over sample E with 0.5wt% Pd loading with 2h. And the percentages of degradation over sample E, sample B, sample A and P25 within 3h were 92.5%, 80.1%, 53.6% and 67.8%, respectively. Accordingly, the decomposed acetaldehyde was confirmed to almost completely convert into CO2 over all the samples, as shown in Fig. 10b and d. Considering that the highly mesoporous PdOx/WO3/TiO2 nanofibers showed far superior photocatalytic activity to other three photocatalysts under visible light and UV–vis light irradiation, we try to explain that the introduction of WO3 composite and the thoroughly and uniformly mesoporous structure formed by stepwise decomposition of DIAD and PVP and the deposition of the Pd nanoparticles are three key factors that improve the photocatalytic activity. The energy edge positions of WO3 and TiO2 play a critical role in determining the migration of the photoexcited electron-hole carriers. As shown in Scheme 1 a, when PdOx/WO3/TiO2 samples were subjected to visible irradiation, the role of WO3 introduced into the anatase TiO2 is a sensitizer to absorb visible light and PdOx cocatalysts on WO3 act as an electron acceptor, whereas the photogenerated holes migrate in the opposite direction, i.e. from the lower-lying valence WO3 band to the valence band of TiO2. This is beneficial to the effective separation of electron-hole pair photoexcited on WO3 and thus inhibits their recombination. This shifted photogenerated holes can direct oxidize the reactants. Moreover, as reported before, the WO3/TiO2 composite has the higher acidity and affinity for chemical species, thus, the surface of WO3/TiO2 composite can absorb more OH or H2O and produce a larger amount of OH radicals with the reaction of holes [23–25]. The result of the XPS analysis of O 1s in the WO3/TiO2 nanofibers (sample E) in Fig. 7c was consistent with the results in the above literatures. In addition, it has been well studied that the low conduction band level of WO3 (+0.5V vs. NHE) is more positive than the reduction potentials of O2 (O2/O2 − =−0.56V vs. NHE; O2/HO2 =−0.13V vs. NHE), and thus increases the recombination of photogenerated electrons and holes, leading to ultralow catalytic activity [42–44]. When the surface of WO3 was deposited with PdOx, it can proceed multielectron oxygen reduction (O2 +2H+ +2e− →H2O2, E° (O2/H2O2)=+0.70V vs NHE) as well as Pt [45]. This was evidence by the produced H2O2 amounts which were measured to be 0.89μmol in the solution under the visible light irradiation for 1h.The generated H2O2 was subsequently produce OH by reacting with electrons (H2O2 +e− → OH+OH−) [46] and largely improved the catalytic activity of WO3/TiO2 nanofibers (sample B and E) compared to the pure TiO2 nanofibers (sample A) and P25 under visible irradiation (in Fig. 10a). The effect of the loading amounts of Pd on sample E on the photocatalytic activity was further investigated as shown in Fig. S6. It is clearly indicates that 0.5wt% PdOx-loading produces the most effective photocatalytic activity for sample E on the basis of the CO2 generation from the acetaldehyde decomposition within the initial 30min. An excessive Pd deposition does not enhance the photocatalytic activity due to the photon absorption by the inactive PdOx nanoparticles [47]. On the other hand, when comes to UV–vis irradiation, WO3 and TiO2 can both be photoexcited by UV and UV–vis light, respectively. According to the generally accepted photoexcitation mechanism, the photoexcited electrons from the conduction band of TiO2 can easily diffuse into the conduction band of WO3 [48,49]. WO3 acts as an acceptor of conduction band electrons from TiO2. The photoexcited electrons on conduction band of WO3 and the shifted electrons from TiO2 were further trapped by PdOx cocatalysts, where the multi-electron reduction reaction performs the same as the mentioned above process under visible light. This was evidence by the produced H2O2 amounts which were measured to be 3.12μmol in the solution under UV–vis light irradiation for 1h. Meanwhile, the photogenerated holes in the valence band of WO3 migrate in the valence band of TiO2. Also, this holes can have direct oxidation with pollutants and react with the absorbed H2O or −OH to generate OH. In addition, a part of photoexcited electrons are trapped by Pd cocatalysts loaded on the surface of TiO2 and perform the one-electron reduction reaction with the dissolved O2 to produce O2 −, which has the highest oxidation power and the sufficiently long lifetime among all the active oxidizing species [50]. This also the reason that sample E with 0.5wt% PdOx loading has the highest photocatalytic activity under UV–vis light irradiation relative to sample A, sample B and sample E (Fig. 10c). For detecting the active species during the photocatalytic reactivity over sample E with 0.5wt% PdOx loading under UV–vis light irradiation, OH, O2 − and holes (h+) were tested by adding 1.0mM isopropyl alcohol (IPA, a quencher of OH), p-benzoquinone (BQ, a quencher of O2 −) and triethanolamine (TEOA, a quencher of h+), respectively. The results in Fig. 11 a show that OH, O2 − and holes (h+) are involved in the photocatalytic reaction in sample E with 0.5wt% PdOx loading. Another key factor that enhanced the photocatalytic activity of sample E with PdOx loading is the highly mesoporous structure of sample E. The unique highly and uniformly mesoporous structure and the more homogenous and smaller nanosized particles caused by the stepwise decomposition of porogenic agent DIAD and PVP skeleton largely enhanced the specific surface area of the sample E and thus increased the contact probability between the photocatalyst and the organic molecules which offered more catalytic sites for photocatalytic reaction. Moreover, the mesoporous structure made the crossed nanofibers integrated and allowed the effective transportation of reaction samples and largely reduced the influence of the particle aggregation problem. The highly and uniformly mesoporous structure can also enhance the utilization of scattered light [51,52]. When the mesoporous nanofibers are irradiated by light, a considerable part of the photons are not directly absorbed by fibers, but can be trapped within the mesopores and then repeated reflection until being completely absorbed. Thus, the advantages mentioned above contribute to the highest photocatalytic activity of highly mesoporous WO3/TiO2 nanofibers with 0.5wt% PdOx loading compared to other photocatalysts. Finally, to investigate the reusability of the highly mesoporous PdOx/WO3/TiO2 nanofiber, the used PdOx/WO3/TiO2 photocatalysts were recovered and reused for photocatalytic decomposition of acetaldehyde under UV–vis light irradiation, compared to that of P25, as shown in Fig. 11. There is just little loss of CO2 generation from the decomposition of acetaldehyde for the highly mesoporous PdOx/WO3/TiO2 nanofibers, which may be attributed to the weight loss of the photocatalysts in each recycle run or the various uncertainties in experimental operation. While the activity of P25 appeared to obviously decline after three cycles out of the operation error. This difference could be attributed that the fact that 1D nanofibers geometry construction could remarkably reduce the aggregation compared to P25, which contributed to the stable photocatalytic performance. 4 Conclusions We have demonstrated highly mesoporous PdOx/WO3/TiO2 ternary hybrid photocatalysts prepared by the porogenic agent-involved electrospinning process combined with a subsequent photodeposition. The stepwise decomposition of the introduced DIAD and PVP skeleton promotes the formation of the thoroughly and uniformly mesoporous structure in the WO3/TiO2 nanofiber compares to that obtained without DIAD addition. This highly mesoporous structure largely enhances the specific surface area of the composite photocatalyst. The higher degradation of acetaldehyde solution was obtained by the highly mesoporous WO3/TiO2 assisted by PdOx nanoparticles loading than that over P25 and pure TiO2 nanofibers obtained without WO3 coupling and DIAD addition. This higher photodecompositon capacity of acetaldehyde over the highly mesoporous PdOx/WO3/TiO2 nanofibers under visible light and UV–vis light irradiation arises from the synergy between the introduction of the WO3, the unique mesoporous structure and the deposition of the PdOx nanoparticles. This present work may open the new doors for the preparation of thoroughly and uniformly mesoporous nanofibers toward the high-performances in the applications of solar cell, lithium-ion batteries and H2 energy production besides the application in photocatalysis. coredata.dc:description: Highly mesoporous WO3/TiO2 nanofibers were fabricated through the combination of an advanced electrospinning strategy in the presence of porogenic agent and the subsequent heat treatment. It was found that the introduced porogenic agent of diisopropyl azodiformate (DIAD) within the precursor solution plays a crucial role on the formation of highly mesoporous WO3/TiO2 nanofibers, enabling their mesopores tunable. The obtained mesoporous nanofibers from the stepwise decomposition of DIAD and polymer skeleton possess more homogeneous and smaller pore sizes in their morphology and thus a higher surface area than that obtained without porogenic agent. The highest surface area can reach 92.3m2g−1, which is ca. 5 times larger than that of the pure TiO2 nanofibers obtained without DIAD addition. These highly mesoporous WO3/TiO2 nanofibers were further modified by PdOx nanoparticles via photodeposition. The as-fabricated mesoporous PdOx/WO3/TiO2 hybrid nanofibers exhibit excellent photocatalytic activity and significant stability towards acetaldehyde decomposition compared to the conventional nanofibers under visible light and UV–vis light irradiation. The present work suggests a facile preparation of PdOx loaded mesoporous WO3/TiO2 nanofibers, which may provide new solution to prepare the inorganic nanofibers with highly mesoporous structure.
coredata.dc:title: Fabrication of PdOx loaded highly mesoporous WO3/TiO2 hybrid nanofibers by stepwise pore-generation for enhanced photocatalytic performance
